Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	End of him triangular, its ends are acute.
Fit ex Indi.	Suited from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And likewise it is necessary that all which we have said of the Razors, and Scissors, and Saw be.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	On the incisions of the limbs and on the locking of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The extremities may become putrid, either through an external cause or through an internal one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	If, however, you have treated the corruption with medicine, and it does not respond to treatment: and you see that corruption is affecting a limb, but it does not affect any other part: then you should cut off that limb as far as the corruption extends, so that the sick person may be cured by it, or by the greater harm of losing the limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that this happens is that the limb becomes discolored, until it putsrefies: either because fire has scorched it, or after it has become black from corruption: until the putrefaction extends to that limb, and spreads throughout the whole body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, when you make the incision, and likewise if the cause of the corruption is from the percussion of certain venenosos [venomous plants]: such as the sea scorpion, the horse-mussel, the mustard, and others.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If, however, the corruption or the percussion is at the tip of a finger, then cut off that finger, and not leave any space for the corruption, so that it may be cut off up to the remaining hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And likewise if it happens in a hand, then cut off that hand from the root of the nail, and not leave any space for the corruption, until it takes hold in the arm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it has lodged in it, then cut off the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	If, however, the corruption passes through, and you see it around the elbow: then death is in that limb.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And administering other than this medicine, is a matter of dosage.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And likewise do for the foot, if the corruption has lodged in a finger, then cut off that foot from the ankle joint: and if it has lodged in the shin bone of the foot, then cut off the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If it has risen up to the knee, then cut the leg at the joint of the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	If the corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no hope for recovery, only amputation and abandonment to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the way to incise the limb, or to sever it, is to grasp the lower ligament, which you wish to incise: and seize a second ligament above the spot.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And extend one minister of the ligaments downward: and extend another minister of the ligaments upward upward.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you shall separate the flesh which is between the two ligaments, with a sharp blade, until the whole flesh is separated.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it shall be incised, or severed.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And you should put a cloth over all the parts, so that the blade does not touch the sound place: and it shall happen to the sick with added injury, and feverishness.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If, however, there should be a flow of blood inward while you are operating, then quickly cauterize the place: or put some dust upon it which stops the blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your own medication, until it is completed.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable ligament, and take care of it, until it is healed.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I will tell you what happened to the man in his foot, this same thing that I am telling you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because it happened in his black foot, with the scorch which resembles the burning of fire: and that corruption first began in his toe, until it covered his whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Then that man came forward of himself, after he had seen the corruption inciding in his member with its swiftness, which he knew from its pain and scorch: and he incised himself at the joint, and was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after he had passed a long time, that corruption happened to him again in the same way in his little finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	Then he came to me, and I tried to restore that excess with him when I put on the hand with medicine after washing his body: and that excess did not recur, and it began to incise in another finger: until the corruption began in the hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	I therefore held him by the hand to examine it; and I did not wish to do so, hoping that there would be no excess of blood from his wound; and I was also afraid of death from the incision of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For the strength of the man was greater than the danger.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	And after he had despaired of me, he turned back to his own country; and he came to me because I desired him, and he struck his entire hand on mine; and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I have not brought this story forward except as an aid to what is about to happen in this type of illness; and that it may be a sign, and according to which it occurs.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Regarding the treatment of gangrene, and the quality of clotting with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 100.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When gangrene occurs in some fleshy part of the body and the space of gangrene is prolonged until it forms a clot: then it bursts, or pierces, and what is in it comes out, leaving a hollow place like a wound; and the skin that is on top of it looks like a thin cloth; and does not penetrate to its ultimate corruption, nor does it enter the mouth, the nerves, or the ligaments: it deserves to be called Sinus: but it is not so named; but if it continues to prolong, until it penetrates the corruption into some of these members, then it is called a Fistula, or a pus-hole.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the care of it is that you strike off all its skin as if it were unwound; and above all when it has become thin, and looks like cloth; and trust that it will not adhere to the place because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If, however, you hope that the skin will adhere and not follow that last consequence of corruption: and if there is a thickness of flesh on the skin, then treat it with Clister; and you are to consider as regard Sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large, and the pus that is discharged from it has a foul odor; then clisterize it with Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, oil, and zinc, taking equal parts, mixing them together in wine; and let them boil on the fire until they turn red: and make them into a paste of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from him what you need: and dissolve it with water and honey, and clisterize it with the sinuses: and tighten the opening of it, and let the medicine go into it for the quantity of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract him with an expression: let him be days until the sinuses are cleaned up and the foul smell is gone.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And sometimes when it is clisterized with black water, when this medicine is not present with you: and it is, so that you take the ash of wood that has been burned, or the ash from oak wood: and you pour it over her water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then dip it, and clisterize it with it until you are sure that the sinuses have been washed away.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	That if the sick person does not tolerate the Egyptian medicine or water of ash, then clisterize it with water and honey, in which there is already some crushed zingiber mixed.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or clisterize it with honey and wine because the property of honey is that it cleanses and washes away, and the wine makes the sinuses adhere, especially when there is an abundance of astringency and dryness in it.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you do this sometimes, and are sure that the corruption of the sinuses has already gone away: then clisterize it with him so that he can generate flesh in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is so that you take from the plaster of dyphpine: and dissolve it with rose oil, and wine astringent: or clisterize it with some other medicines, and with ointments, whose properties I have written in the book of ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	That if the opening of the sinus is tight, in which the tube of the clister does not enter: then increase it with a little iron: or put in it the licorice that is soaked in Egyptian ointment, or in basilic ointment, until it is increased.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the opening is also wide, then join the lips together with a suturing thread: and let go from it the quantity that enters the clister without adding anything to it.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And likewise if the opening from which the infection flows is raised higher up: then dry it off in a lower place that is in itself, so that the infection may flow out of it down to below: for when the infection is constricted in the depth of the sinus, it prevents meat from growing in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is not possible for you to dry out the sinus all around below it according to your wish: then be careful, so that you prepare the limb with preparation through which the infection may flow out of it easily according to what is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Be careful that nothing of the pus is left in it at all: and take the solid medicines which are placed over the wound, fitting for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them over the cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And have a cloth of such a quantity that it may come into communication with all the sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with forceps in the direct opening of the sinus a hole, a little larger hole.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend from the unguent a soft cloth over another cloth according to the quantity of the hole: and place it on the limb in a distant position from the opening of the sinus, so that the exit of pus from it may be facilitated: and do not remove the large cloth until after some days.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	But that which is over the opening of the sinus, is he whom you stir up every hour, so that he moves out what is gathered in it from pus: and know that the infection which flows out of it, is very much or little: or digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And with this repeatedly consider the place of the sinus itself, whether it feels pain in its lord or not: and whether there is no pain in it, and whether there is a swelling in it, or not.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	And when you extend your medicine so, and see the matter which flows out over the opening of the sinus: then know that the sinus is already attached, or is approaching attachment: so then dissolve it in the morning, or in the third day: and when you have dissolved the wound, then change the cloth, and renew the unguent.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if it is discharged from the Sinus after a long time, then do not despair of its adherentium, for the cure approaches, because there are people who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and from them come those who act opposite to it.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if it is discharged from the sinus after many days of pus, then you should know that the sinus does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	But if the adherentium of the sinus is delayed, and its duration is prolonged: then add to it, that doctors may make medicine, so that it is in its substance moist and in its virtue dry: like the unguent of dyafinicon, when it is added to it superfluitas additionis ex zegi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the greatest last, when it is cured, it is, that you take the unguent of dyafinicon, and dissolves with olive oil, and drips on the old wine with equal substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then put it together with it, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And also does this action similar to this, when the unguent of dyafinicon is not present with you, honey, when it is heated, and you use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh and aloe and olive oil: grind them all together, and powder it over honey while it is on fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then tie a cloth over the wound and tighten it around the sinus: and grind with honey that you have prepared, until it has thickened: and powder the species on top of it, and put it on the cloth, and tighten it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And when these are administered to it, the long arnebia, and the roots of the star lily, and is a lily: and flour of herbs, and centaurea.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them simple, or mixed together, grind it up, and sift the powder over honey that you have prepared, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the duration of the sinus is prolonged, and it does not heal with this cure: then you should know that there is corruption in its depth: or it already makes an impression on the bones, or on the other hard parts of the body, or ligaments: then care for the wound with surgery, as has been stated.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	On the treatment of a sprained ankle and a sore toenail, and the addition of a cut finger and an incision.
Caput XCI.	De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	On the treatment of a sprained ankle and a sore toenail, and the addition of a cut finger and an incision
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	If it is prolonged and neglected in its treatment, and becomes inflamed, or putrid, until it corrode the nail-root: and perhaps it corrupts all of it, and perhaps the corruption reaches to the mouth, until there is a foul odor; and the end of the finger becomes swollen, and its color turns black.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When you treat it then, with the same treatment as we have spoken of in the division, and your treatment does not help: then you should cut away the whole excess that remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then anoint the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	The cautery of a wound is very strong.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If the mouth is healthy, and the nail also is healthy, and the little additions of the nail are pressing on the flesh inwardly, and they begin to hurt it: then you should place a very fine ray under the corner of the nail that hurts the flesh, and push it upwards: and cut off the flesh easily, and place over it what remains of the flesh from the medicines burning, and the corrosion, until all of it is moved away.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat that with ointment, until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If the corruption has already pressed into the mouth, then you should cut off that mouth, and take it out: for it does not heal at all while there is still corruption in it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see the corruption and the corruption spreading in the finger, then cut it at one end, according to what has been said above in its recollection.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat that, until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If, however, a toenail is sore or has been hit, and there is a sharp pain with it, then you should first draw blood from the nail.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then cut the nail with a sharp chisel from above down to the eye.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And beware that the cut does not go into the flesh under the nail, for you may cause a very painful pain by doing so, and it will be a cause of the birth of flesh added to the place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the place with the medicine that relieves the pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The finger added which is born in some men's hands, perhaps is flesh all over: and perhaps there are bones in it, and perhaps there is a nail in it: and the birth of some of their fingers is in the root of the tendon, or its birth is in some of its nodules.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	So this one who is born in the nodules of a finger does not move: and perhaps he who is born by the joint of a finger moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, in the case of the flesh which is born, it is easy to cut him.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, so that you might strike him at his root with a chisel.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But the cure for him whose birth is in the root of the tendon is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore, abstain from cutting him.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	In that one who is born in a finger at the last nodule, then it should be that you strike the first flesh of his incision round up to the mouth.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then close the mouth with one of those knives suitable for closing it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for the man, until he is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	The healing of the fingers which happens from one side to another, often happens or is born from the birth of man, that is, is born with him, or from the healing of a wound, or fire burn, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore, it should be so that he removes this healing, until the fingers regain their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them a chisel, or cloth dipped in rose oil: that they may not heal quickly, and separate them: or place between them a thin lead plate, until the place heals as it should.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And likewise if some consolidation of the fingers with the palm should occur, then dry that consolidation, according to how it was prepared and suited to the form of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	On Incision The Fault.
Caput XCII.	Chapter LII. On the Head.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Veins that are swollen and full of melancholy humors, which occur in many parts of the body, especially in the thighs, since they are the main limbs for moving, working and carrying.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore, it is necessary that you should treat the body's discharge from black cholera by a strong emission of urine.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then, the patient's bloodletting should be done in the main room.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The treatment of these veins with iron is done according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One is that they should be made to sit and black blood should be drawn from them.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other method is that the vein should be ligated and all of it should be extracted.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The sectioning of this is done according to this mode.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Wrap the thigh with hot water until the thick, foul blood resolves.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then tie the thigh of the patient from the upper part of the hip down to the knee with the sutural thread, and tie it up tightly.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then dry one, two, or three veins that are widely separated.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then ligate it, that is to say, extract blood from the lower part of the thigh in your hand all the way up, and above all, bloodletting must be done to the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then dry the leg down to the toe: until it runs out of blood, as much as you see will be enough, and as much as the nurse' strength can tolerate.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then tie it up: and tell him to refrain from foods that generate black cholera, and again to administer urine emission and bloodletting when the veins are filled up, and let him feel the pain of the illness.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation of this is done according to this mode.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Scrape away the crust, if there are many hairs in it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then insert the finger into water: or wet it with warm water, until it turns red and the veins swell: or exercise it firmly, if there is no water available, until it warms up.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin with a direct stroke along the length: or at the end near the knee, or in the lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with a hook, and scrub the vein from all sides until it appears to touch: and at its appearance, you will see it turn red to blackish-red.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When you remove it from the skin, you will see it white as a string.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert under it Radium, until it comes out and leaves the skin: hang it with a blind hook, soft.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry another section next to that section with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrub the skin from the top part of the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then rub it with Radium as you did, and hang it with another hook as you did before.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry another section, or multiple sections, if you can tolerate it.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then rub it and cut it at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then remove it to the section above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this, until you remove it from the upper section; or with higher sections, until it comes out completely; then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If it does not submit to you when you try to remove and rub it; then insert a sharp instrument with two strong threads, tie it, and pull it out: or insert under it Radium: and turn your hand around all sides, until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	Then tie it so that it does not cut you.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it cuts you, it is difficult for you to remove it deeply; and it enters into the body and leaves a scar behind it.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	So when you have extracted it all: then place it on the wound's site, soaked with wine and oil rose, or oil; and cure it itself, until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vine is contracted, it has a twist to its parts that requires an adjustment to those parts, and it is not like what we said before regarding straightness: then you must find on top of it for all parts of its twist, and places of its adjustment.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then hang it with hooks until you have raised it all: and be careful when you cut through your part above it, or hurt any wounds: because it will be difficult to raise it over yourself, or to extract it.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore, preserve your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	Form a shape of the wound when the vine heals.
Forma Vncini caeci.	Form a hook shape.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not curvy like the other hooks, and it does not have a sharp extreme, so that it does not hurt the skin: and it has a dull bend, soft: because if it were thin, it would hit the skin with its thinness: but it has excess dullness, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of a vein from the leg.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter 83.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is produced in the legs on warm lands, such as the Alps and the Arab lands, and in dry and hot lands that have little tenderness, that is, where no grass grows, nor trees.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is produced in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is from the decay that happens under the skin, just as it happens within the bodies of snakes and worms and scabies, and the worms that grow between the skin and meat.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this vein is, that inflammation occurs in the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then a sore place forms.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to come out of that place of its sore, as if it were the root of a plant, or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	Now then, when this extremity appears, you should fasten a plumb weight onto it; the weight of which is two drachmas and a knot, up to two drachmas; and let the lead hang from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever then this leaves something on the outside, you should fix it into lead, and mark it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If then it is prolonged a long time, then cut away part of it, and fasten the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it away at its roots before it has left all of it.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut it, it will contract, and go into the flesh; and it will cause an ulcer to form, and corruption in the place, and a bad wound.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it should be handled gently, and removed slowly, until it has left all of it, and nothing remains of it in the body; and from this one vein emerges in some men, which is five palms long and ten fingers' breadth across.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And it has already reached me, for it came out of twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if it should happen to you during the time of your own treatment: then insert a needle into the hole, and pierce it with a long one, along with the flesh; until all that is in it has come out of it, all of it putrefied: and administer corruption of the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	And then take care of yourself in curing ulcers.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears in the joint of the foot, or in the foot itself: and it has many openings, and emerges from every opening a branch.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore take care of herself, as we have said in the division, and with what is added to it.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	On the cutting off above the worms which come out under the skin, and it is called a bad fever.
Caput XCIIII.	Head LXXIV.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This fever is called in our country Bouine fever: because it often happens to the bouis, and there is one kind of it which springs up between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And he felt through the entire body, ascending and descending: and it was shown to him through the sense of touch during his walk, from limb to limb, until he had finished everywhere where he had stopped on the skin, and he had gone away.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And his generation is from the corruption of some of the humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As do happen worms and snakes, that is, worms and roundworms in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And they are afraid of his malice.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	For when he felt through the body, and went up to the head, and came to a place: then perhaps he would open within him, and go out, and destroy his eye: and this has happened many times.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	But when you are going to care for him, and take him out, then that should not happen except through his sense of touch during his walk, and the appearance of it.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, you need to tie down what is above him, and what is under him with strong constriction by means of a ligament.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry off on top of him, and take him out.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	That if he should sink into the flesh, and not harm himself: then place over the place a caustic with fire, until he dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater than that which he fears is his corruption, which corrupts his eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	But if you see him already come to the head near the eye, then tie under him with good constriction by means of a ligament.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry off on top of him, and take him out.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that the sick one should use his own purification, with medicines solving the bad korosive humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him guard himself from foods that generate corruption.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	关于疾病的切开部分纳基尔。
Caput XCV.	第50章
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	这种疾病在我们的土地上被称为纳基尔：并在某些肢体部位痛苦，然后从肢体转移到另一肢体。
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I have already seen him myself, according to what I tell you now.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I am called to a sick woman with some ailments.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And he detected his arm, and saw the swelling of the lung in the vein of the shoulder.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour had passed, I saw one swelling run up with a whip, as it runs on the skin, faster than it can be: so that it is like silver running, when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	So the pain receded from that spot, and was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then I sat for an hour, and it ran through the rest of the body until it reached the other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then he told me that he was shaking all over his whole body, according to which I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	So I was amazed at the speed of the changing of its member from one member to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And neither before that did I see this sickness with my eyes in such a way.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I saw many, who found pain changing from one member to another: and I did not see him with my eyes, as I saw him in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that was it, unless because the woman was one of those who are found with dry lungs detected by the touch: so therefore this seems to be the reason for the change in sensation.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that those who are delicious and have wet bodies do not appear in this way, by reason of the hidden lungs.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When then you will see his cure, and the patient feels pain: then if it appears to you with your eye, as we have said, then squeeze him above himself, and below him quickly: and dry above himself, until this windiness is driven out: and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	But if you do not see him with your eyes: then the cure of the body, and with it that he drives out windiness, and makes them come to a head with pills of fennel, and with those of serapine, and others like them.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	On the Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter LXVI. On the Extraction of Arrows.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows differ according to their species and according to the places in which they enter the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Of these arrows there are several kinds, some having large points and some small; some are conic and some flat.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	Of these there are three-angle arrows.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And of these there are arrows with tongue-shaped heads.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And of these there are arrows with spined heads.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	These, however, that enter the body according to the limbs, fall into two ways.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	For example, if they enter the main limbs, such as the brain, heart, liver, lung, kidneys, intestines, and bladder, or similar organs.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	But if it falls into one of these main limbs and you see the signs of death that I shall describe to you, then you should withdraw the arrow at once, for death will soon follow otherwise.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	But if these bad signs are not evident to you and the arrow does not enter deeply into the body, then withdraw it and be concerned about the wound itself.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For when the arrow enters the skull and passes through the bone and exits above the brain, it causes a kind of dizziness, and swelling, and trembling in the eyes, and swelling, and spasm, and confusion of thought, and amnesia, and colic.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood will come from the nose or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech will be lost and words destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And a white pus-like substance may come from the wound's site.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And there will come out a substance similar to meat juices.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	But if you see these signs, then refrain from treating it, and withdraw the arrow if it has not come out.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow that enters the heart are: it is near the left nipple; and when it feels like it is fixed in a hard place rather than in a soft one.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps arrows are a movement similar to pulsation; and black blood runs from the ulna.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And then follows that coldness of limbs, and cold sweat, and fainting fits.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	So you see, death has come by all means.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And when an arrow hits the lung, the exit of bloody blood from the ulna; and when the neck is injured, it turns pale, and changes color in the nurse.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he breathes out great, deep breaths; and seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	That if an arrow falls into the breast-bone, which is within a few inches of the back; then it is near to the ribs: and causes great pain with loud breathing, with gasps: and all the arms tremble.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if an arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps it has come out from some undigested food in the ulna.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if an arrow falls into the belly and is locked up in it: then some stool comes out from the ulna, or a piece of dung, or disrupted intestine.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is therefore no hope for his cure, nor for the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	That if an arrow falls into the bladder, and urine comes out: and proceeds from it something to the outside, and the pain is stronger on the sick; then you know that it is deadly.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The rest of the limbs, such as the face, neck, throat, tongue, jaw, spine, femur, hip, leg, and feet, are saved according to various dispositions; but when an arrow does not hit a blood vessel or nerve, and is not deadly.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you that I saw such things as these arrows; so that you may understand by this about your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is, because a man was struck by an arrow in the tear duct of his eye, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	I therefore removed it from his own side, under the fat of his ear: and he recovered, and there was no harm to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I drew out another arrow from the Jew, which had fallen into his fat under his eye-lid: and the arrow was now hidden, and I did not succeed in drawing it out but for its narrow end, by which it stuck to his wood; and this was a great arrow of the Turks' arrows, with a soft iron; whereon there were no folds.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	So the Jew recovered, and there was no harm to his eye with any harm.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I drew out another arrow from the throat of a Christian man.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And this was an arrow made in the Arab way, and it was one whose end was pointed.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	So I followed up on it with two other arrows between two guides; and now it was submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I was careful with it until I drew it out: and the Christian man recovered.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I drew out another arrow from the belly of a man which had fallen into his belly: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After he had therefore passed thirty days, and there was no change in him with regard to his disposition, I followed up on the arrow: and I was careful about it, and drew it out: and he recovered, and there was no harm to him with any harm.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man whom the arrow had fallen into his back, and the wound was closed over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After he had therefore been seven years, the arrow came out at the root of his thigh.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman to whom an arrow had fallen into her belly, and the wound was closed over it, and the arrow remained within her: nor was there any change in her disposition with regard to her natural operations, and the woman found no harm in him with regard to any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man to whom an arrow had fallen into his face: and the wound was closed, and it remained, not finding him much pain: and there were many such things like these.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I drew an arrow from the king's Prince, which had fallen to him in the middle of his nose, and had already declined towards the right side about as much: and the whole arrow was hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	So I was called to cure him after the fall of the arrow for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I then found a very stiff arrow shaft.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I then examined it with a delicate touch, and I did not feel it: but he himself perceived the prick and pain on his right cheek.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	So I hoped that it was the prick from the end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	So I plastered the place with plaster where there was the attractive and digesting power, confiding to myself that it would heal, and I would see a sign of the arrow so that I could cut it off: but there happened nothing in the place which indicated that the arrow had followed the place.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	So I kept plastering over him for many days: and nothing happened, and the bone was well hardened by then: but he remained sick because of the loss of the arrow from his space for some day, until he felt the arrow in his nose on a certain day.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me about that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	So I put acute medicine on that bone for many days, until it was opened: and when I examined him, I felt a very slight prick of the arrow which was holding onto the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added more of the acute medicine to the opening of the wound, until the end of the arrow was clearly visible: and there passed by me with him about four months of time.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then when the bone had strengthened, and it seemed possible to me to put my finger into it, and move it, and it would not come out: so I kept up the delicate work, and devised means for it, until on a certain day I came upon it with crooked fingers, according as the shape of them was at the end of the passage, until I drew it out.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I repaired the break.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And the physicians indeed say that the nose cartilage is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	So I repaired it, and the fracture was solid, and the health was restored to its whole strength: nor did it harm him in any way at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of the extraction of certain arrows: that you set down that rule and significance about it which I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For the parts of this art and their distinctions are not to be understood with narration: nor does that book comprehend them, and the crafty craftsman compares little with much: and when he is away, he has what is missing, and finds a new operation and a new instrument for the descent of foreign things of this art when they happen.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	So I say that arrows do not come out of the member from which they are fixed, except according to two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by attraction from the place from which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by the opposite part of the other.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which comes out where it entered, or is an arrow going out in a fleshly place: and is attracted, and goes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	That if it does not obey to go out at the time at which it falls: then you must let it go for a few days, until the flesh that is around it putsrefies: and the attraction of it will be allayed, and its exit.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And likewise if it is broken into a bone, and does not obey to come out for you: then let it go also for a few days: and again with the attraction and movement every day, until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	That if it does not obey to come out for you after a few days: then you must drill in the circle of the arrow in the bone from all sides with a sharp bit, until the arrows become larger.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract it, and pull it out.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	But if the arrow is fixed in the bone of the skull, and has already gone into one of the vents of the brain, and there is a certain accident of those diseases which I have mentioned: then abstain from attracting the arrow, and let it go, until it has become even with that after a few days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	If an arrow has pierced the skin, then death should not be prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	But if the arrow has not lodged in the body but only pierces the skin, and remains there for a few days without causing any harm to him; then one should try to pull out the arrow with tools and draw it out.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is firmly lodged and does not obey you when you try to pull it out; then apply tereba to the place around the arrow, as I have told you: then attend to the wound until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	But if the arrow has already gone deep into the body and is hidden and concealed from sight; then try to find it out.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	But if you feel it, then pull it out with some tools that are suitable for pulling it out.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	But if you cannot reach it due to the constriction of the wound and the length of the arrow deep inside; and there is no bone or nerve or vein at that place: then try to find it out until the wound becomes bigger, so that it can be possible to pull out the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	That if there are ears that hold the arrow, then free the meat that is attached to them from all sides with all your skill and tools; and try, if you cannot bring about the release of the meat in the breaking of the ears or their twisting, until it is released.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you try to pull out the arrow, in whichever part it is, then use your twisted hands with forceps to all sides until you make it come out: and use the finest tools so that the arrow does not break, and so that it becomes difficult for you to attract it and pull it out.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	That if you cannot reach it in one hour, then leave it for a few days until what is around it begins to rot.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat it: for often the flow of blood causes ease; then apply what I have said in our book on curing; and guard your skill from cutting the flesh or a nerve or a vein.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer art every way which thou canst of the bow of Sagittarius: and let it be with ease, and quietness, or tardiness, and firmness, as I have told thee.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that you do when you shoot Sagittarius, so that the injured person is in the same position as was the case with Sagittarius at the fall of Sagittarius in himself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For it is more safe.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	But if you are not able to do that, then administer what you can of the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	But the arrow which comes from the opposite side, or has already gone out a little towards the outside: or makes a protuberance at the extreme end of Sagittarius by feeling from the upper part of the skin near it, and you see it protruding: then cut over it, and let the section be according to the quantity that it holds in it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then attract it: for it becomes easy to come out.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	But if it is held in the bone, then twist your hand according to the roundness, until Sagittarius presses upon the bone and strengthens itself on it: then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: leave it for a few days: then repeat it, until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	That if the wood of Sagittarius is in it, then push it with that.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	But if it has fallen wood, and you can administer the push: then introduce into it the tool that is sharp, so that the sharpness of it enters into the end of Sagittarius: then push it with that.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	But if Sagittarius is drawn up, then push it with an instrument which enters into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	For the arrow glides through it.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	That if Sagittarius is poisoned, then you must, so that the sharpness of the meat is in it, where the poison is: if you can do that.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then take care of it with that which comes to that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	That if Sagittarius is falling in the breast, or in the belly, or in the groin, and it is close to that which you touch with the hand, and can cut over it: then cut off, and cause away from the incision of the vein, or nerve, and take it out.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then cut the bone, if you see it, and heal that, until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of the pincers, with which the arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	They should be made similar in shape to the ear, which is made like a wedge: when they grasp on to the arrow, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And there are many kinds of them, great and small and medium, according to the quantity of the size of the arrow and its width and the constriction of the wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The form of the spur.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of the spur is deaf.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the extreme end of the spur like a ray, so that it may be introduced into the hole in the conic arrow, and driven with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	This end of the spur is conic like a feather: so that it may be introduced into the hole of the arrow and its impulsion.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	Of phlebotomy of veins.
Caput XCVII.	Head 57.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	There are thirty veins of phlebotomy, from which the custom of bloodletting is made in the body.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these there are sixteen in the head: two pulsating veins, which are behind the ears, called the two herbs; and two arteries, which appear at the two temples; and two veins which come from the two eyelids of the two eyes, called the two gaze; and a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead; and a vein which is in the tip of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two arteries are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	These are called Algecirach's veins.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	But the veins of phlebotomy in the arms are five in all the arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the cephalica vein, and it comes from the side of the skull: and it is called the common head vein.
Et Fusca.	And the wound.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And the wound is good, and it is made up of a branch of the basilica, and a branch of the skull: and it is called by the people a good part of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the basilica, and it is placed in the domestic lateral: and it is also called Titlicarus.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And they call it a good part of the hand.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the tendon of the biceps, and it is placed on the shaft: and this is that from which blood is drawn, and this is that which appears above the thumb with a visible line of tension.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the bursa salis, and it is good part that is between the ring finger and the little finger: and there are two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	In the leg and in the foot there are three good parts.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of these is that which is under the thumb with a green edge from the side.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the saphenous vein, and its location is near the heel from the inside.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the third is the nerve: and its location is near the heel on the outside.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	In the other leg, there are three similar parts.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	Regarding the veins of the two ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The phlebotomy of the two veins that are behind the ears, it is an ancient practice to prevent nosebleeds, hemorraging, and a headache-causing condition, and to treat a bad ulcer on the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of phlebotomy depends on the skill of the one who does it.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is good for a person to wash their head, and to rub the occiput with a rough cloth.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then tie the injured neck with a cloth, until the two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their locations are behind the ears in two depressed spots on the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	So go and feel with your finger, and where you feel the pulse of these veins below your finger, there are the marks with the cautery.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take a cauterizing knife, and this one is called the "incisor.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then introduce him under the youth in the wound, until the phlebotome reaches the mouth.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then wash your hands with soap and water, and cut the skin with a knife, cutting the wound at an angle.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And the length of the incision should be as much as two fingers spread out, or about that: and let go out as much blood as you can.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then tie it up with a powder, and leave it alone until it is healed.
