Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now let us begin with the incision of the ears, and their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	The phlebotomy of the two arteries in the temples.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	But the two arteries which are in the two temples, and which are subject to headaches of old standing, and which have a swollen vein, and a drooping eyelid: and run over the course of the flowing blood, which is acute, towards the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And what is the quality of phlebotomy? I will tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	Let the sick man stretch his neck very much, until two wounds appear in a noticeable way: and he shall feel the pulse of his ears under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	For then are the signs with the caustic.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then wash the skin of the neck with soap and water, and put in the phlebotome above it, and wash the blood away upwardly.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it as you did with the two wounds, and let the blood run out according to your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then dissolve the constriction of the vein, and place your finger on a wound for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then put powder and dust on it, and tighten the constriction with a strong hand: and let go of it until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now let us remember the ears, their incision, and their extraction, at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	The phlebotomy of the forehead after phlebotomy of the head.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The phlebotomy of the forehead is after phlebotomy of the head, for old standing ailments of the face: and for a headache, and redness: and for foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of phlebotomy is according to what I tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The injured man raises his neck with his hand until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument that is called a fossorum.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its form: a curved blade with a hole in the center, resembling an inverted V.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the prominent tip of the fossorum on top of the vein, and strike down upon it with a pin or in some other way: and let the blood flow according to the amount that you want.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then make the hole clean, and tighten it, until it has healed over.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when it opens again with the phlebotomist on the side.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it is not necessary that the phlebotomist be acute of limb, as are the other phlebotomists, so that he have a sharp end of limb.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And make the incision according to the transversion: since the hole is close by: and perhaps, when it is thin, the phlebotomist will break when it is made delicate.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	On phlebotomy of veins in two lacrimal glands.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	But the cutting of two veins that are in the two lacrimal glands of the two eyes, is to cut at the eye from a scab and from a red color; and it will be bad for an eye, and for facial ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of phlebotomy of them is, that he should tighten the neck of the injured man with his hand, so that the vein appears.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then make the incision on them: and you stand over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let the phlebotomy be made according to the transversion a little bit along its length, with a little bit of a blade, for there is no flesh in that place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the phlebotomist is acute of limb, perhaps it will break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let the blood flow according to what you need.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place a cloth over them, and tighten them in one night, and then let them go.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	On the phlebotomy of veins in the nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	But the nasopharyngeal phlebotomy is useful for acute fever, and violent headache, and facial diseases, such as haemorrhage, and redness that occurs on the face; above all when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of its phlebotomy, so that it tightens the neck of the ill person.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take the nose of him with your left hand, and take up a fine, long needle; and fix it in the middle of his larynx, between that which divides the nose according to its straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	For the vein does not appear there to the sense, and because the blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And you should let your hand with the needle run out a little with the blood, and make it run out according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind him up for the night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For he will recover very quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	This is a guide to phlebotomy veins of Guidej.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	Of the two veins of Guidej, one is for constriction of the throat, and the beginning of lepra, and melancholic diseases, and impetigo and bad ulcers, and corrosive wounds, that is, herpes zoster.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of their phlebotomy, so that it tightens the neck of the ill person with a ligament: and let the craftsman stand over the head of the nurse, and let the ill person sit on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then phlebotomize a vein that is wide towards its end.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then take out a measured quantity of blood, or according to what you see from necessity, which is for that person.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same with another vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then unravel the ligaments, and tighten two veins in the middle: so that the ill person does not get tight.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let go of it until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the wound will heal.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	This is a guide to phlebotomy veins of Algebirch.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	Veins, however, are the Al-Gharib's phlebotomy aid: because they join to the alcohol in the mouth, and to gingival corruption; and bad ulcers; and labial fissures, and bad ulcers, also those which are in the nose, and about it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of their phlebotomy is that you should make the sick sit before you; and tighten his neck with a band.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then turn his lips and look at two veins; the one is on the right side of his lip, and the second is on the left side of it; and the indication of each is by the color of amber.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And that is true: because around them are small veins, black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	So cut both incisions as you do.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	But if there is doubt over you, and you do not know which of them it is: then turn to the larger incision, and more manifest.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And also make the same for the two veins that are in the upper lip: and much more so runs the custom with him: and cut the two veins that are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	On phlebotomy Veins under the tongue after phlebotomy of the head.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The two veins that are under the tongue are a phlebotomy aid: because phlebotomy of the head is to the pre-eminences which are in the throat, and to the ailments of the uvula, and to the ailments of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of phlebotomy is that the sick sit between your hands towards the sun; and rinse his tongue, and look under his tongue on one side with one vein, and on the other side with another vein: and the color of each of them goes to the color of amber.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	So phlebotomy both: and guard, so that you do not put your hand into their veins afterwards.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under them are arteries, and perhaps it happens that the flow of blood comes out of those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	On three veins on the bed.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The veins which are used for phlebotomy on the thigh, are those in which phlebotomy is done in all people.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And phlebotomy from these two ways is done.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Or with a phlebotome and piercing to the side of the vein; or with oil to relax the skin; or by closing with a phlebotome and a blade, and this is called Alneous.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alneous is, which is suitable for lancing.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from these are species broad and narrow according to the width of the veins and their form; The shape of the phlebotome and the piercing is broad, as you see it.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening closed veins, full, coming from the body, visible, thick, and those which contain thick blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotome is smaller in width, and narrower at the end.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is suitable for phlebotomy of thin veins which contain yellow-colored blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	[This is about] Phlebotomy in the Basilica [church].
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	The Basilica, which is one of three veins to be phlebotomized, is the right one.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from the ailments which are under the throat and neck, because it follows the chest and belly: and it is suitable for a phlebotomist to cut it, so that he may avoid an artery underneath it.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If then one should make a mistake and add to the piercing of the phlebotomy, he will hit the artery, and will spill the flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it should not be pierced with a phlebotome and piercing; but rather cut with the Alneous way.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	That if not the Basilica appears with an obvious sign, then it is necessary to remove it, and to turn it to another one, or to search for some of its branches: or to pierce a place near it, instead of piercing at the branch of the brachial artery.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it is clear and cut with the Alnesil way using a phlebotome, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If, however, you wish to perform venipuncture on yourself, then it is necessary to approach the vein before stricture of the brachial artery, so that you may feel the place where the pulse can be found.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the spot with caustic, then move on to the arm, and dry up the vein by cutting it concavely with Phlebotomus Alnesis, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And let not the pressure fall through space from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see it, when you tighten the ligament, the swelling at the place where you have marked with caustic, then that swelling is swelling of the artery: so remove it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	That if you see blood rise during venipuncture, like a boy's urine, and it is thin blood, red in color: then you will know that it comes from the artery's blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then therefore put your finger on the spot and keep it there for a long time, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If therefore blood is cut off (for it is often cut off) then tighten the arm and let go of it: and so that it does not move: and so that it stands still.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And so that the person does not move for several days, until they are healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If therefore blood does not cut off and does not stop you: and there is no present medicine for you at the moment of your need, then cut the artery, if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities will crack, and blood will be cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take a piece of an axe, and find it: take half, and tighten it to the place where the vein narrows going down, with ligament and powder up to the next day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood is cut off, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	Then if it does not: then take care of the person with the reminder from the place where the powder-cut blood flow was flowing: and cutting off his blood is not difficult in many dispositions, because of the small wound, and possibility of the ligament from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	On the removal of blood from the urethra by Fuscas.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	But the veins of Fuscas are for phlebotomy, which draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower body: therefore, because it is composed of the Basilicae branch and the Cephalica branch, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it belongs to the phlebotomist to make a cut above the vein so that he does not bleed from the vein itself, for under it is the nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	But if he adds a cut to the vein when he is phlebotomizing, and it comes upon the nerve, there results a coma, and difficult recovery, and perhaps no complete healing.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve often appears to sensation.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	But if it is hidden in some people and is thin, and does not show itself: then you must make your cut with Alne's blade, and remove the nerves with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	That if a vein is between two nerves, then find the vein in length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	On the Cephalic vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	But the phlebotomy of the cephalic vein is a technique, because it draws blood from the head, and provides for the ailments of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And you should use your own skill in this vein, if you will, to phlebotomize it with oil-phlebotomy, or with Myrtle-phlebotomy: for all veins are healthier, because they are not under an artery, nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	But it is necessary for you to do the phlebotomy, so that you ask the phlebotomist only at the top of the lacertus, and seek a softer place: and it does not harm him if, after the first strike, you return to it with phlebotomy from time to time.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	But perhaps he abstains from phlebotomy in some people when not struck first, but it does not harm him that abstention from phlebotomy at some time.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the usefulness of phlebotomy and cautions to be observed when observing it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality and the accidents of phlebotomy, for you should consider their correction.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	First of all it is necessary that you should know that phlebotomy is not performed unless in the conservation of health, and its perseverance and caution from the occurrence of ailments.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And to be done phlebotomy on one of three which are in the bed, namely Cephalica, and Fusca, and Basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And to be done phlebotomy at the beginning of spring on a fast, in ver, and summer: and autumn, and winter after feasting, when there are signs of satiety.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And to be done phlebotomy on the first day, or on the third day after having gone past three hours from the day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	But the phlebotomy which is administered in ailments does not have a determined time: but when it provokes convenience and necessity towards it, at night, or during the day, and at any hour, and at all times.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not necessary that boys should be bled before they are fourteen years old.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	And woman who is pregnant should not be bled until the fourth month up to the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	And elderly people should not be bled if they have already passed sixty years old.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	But when someone is to be bled by whatever method it may be: let him purify his intestines before phlebotomy with a soft laxative, if there is much rubbish retained in them: so that the blood does not attract the bowels of the main members from phlebotomy because of putrid effluents.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	And a patient who is to be bled should not be tired, that is, nausea: and drunkards should not be phlebotomized, until they have removed this from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	And an invalid with the gout.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let phlebotomy be repeated after a feverish illness, and forgetfulness, and flow of blood, and multiplication of copulation, and toil, and exercise, and vigils, and fasting, and all that dissolves virtue from the body or from an animal.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider in subtlety of humors before that, if blood is thick with food and drink, and medicines: if possible is to him that.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then bath the water, if not prohibits itself anything: or exercises himself some exercise, to subtilize the blood.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And put phlebotomy its chest in his bosom, about third day, as we have said: and be careful, so that is discharged its chest that day all animal accidents bad: like anger, and wrath, and fear: and all body accidents, like labor, and penalty, and abundance, and those similar.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And make its present these things with which used custom of men from aromatic substance, and odorous matter, and mirth and similar ones by quantity possibility.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then sits the phlebotomator over pulvinar, that is higher than pulvinar phlebotomando: then draws its arm, and rubs it phlebotomator hand itself twice, or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then tie the ligature with corrigia, and wrap it around it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And sit the tightened one temperate, because the tightened one when is unequal, or by superfluity in the tightened one, then prohibits the course of blood: or in the softening, then also prohibits the course of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the tightened one it is necessary, so that rubs the phlebotomando hand itself simultaneously towards innuem, until are inflated veins, and present to sense.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then wipes the phlebotomator phlebotomo with little oil, old its own proper.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then puts the finger its index left hand on itself under place whose phlebotomiam it wanted, little: so that does not flee the vein, and strikes a percussion.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Because from veins is what inuens like a chord fleeing at phlebotomizing: and from them is that is full of air; and when puts the phlebotomo on it, contrahitur against phlebotomo, and deceives the phlebotomator, and does not open the phlebotomo vein: and if opens it, is tightened: so that therefore it is necessary, so that firm phlebotomizer, and sit vigilant in these things all.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then let the patient lie down.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If, however, a new wound is to be made with a single cut, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then that same cut should be made again in another place below or above it with some haste: if the wound does not stop.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	That if it stops bleeding, or the sick person gets better, then let him be discharged after one or two days, and do not tie up the bandage.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	For perhaps the cold will attract the wound to stop bleeding.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	And let no bath be taken.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then let the patient's blood be drained again, if he desires it.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	That if the opening is small, or the blood runs lightly: and be careful not to let out a quantity of blood that is greater than what you intend: then repeat the phlebotomy in the same hole according to the right order, and add a little more during the procedure.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do this with some haste, before the place stops bleeding; for a bleeding place is unpleasant for many people during the course of an operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If you see that the person has already started to bleed, then do not even touch the place above; for it is not good with you to leave anything unfinished.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put something soft on top of the wound; for it smoothes out the course of the blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And is better in this place than oil itself, and than any other oil.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And administer the same oil to all your bloodlettings, except when it is necessary to stop the flow of blood; and make use of a mixture of alfarache and sage, when put on top of the place.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For blood is thinned out and made smooth when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	That if a great amount of blood comes out at the place where you are bleeding, or if it is a small opening with a cut, then come quickly and put on top of the place a sponge soaked in water and salt, slightly warmed up: and tie it for an hour: for it will be made smooth.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	It is necessary that you should do this after the blood has come out from herself with her own complement or from another young one.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	That if it remains in the place after some days of blackening, or reddening, it does not harm that one; and if it is scar, put on it something of aloe, or of dissolved myrrh: or some of the juice of mint, that is, of calamus or like it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And indeed many times there occur hemorrhoids and eminences in the bloodletting at the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	So put your hand on herself, then if it is soft to touch with your pressure on herself, then that eminence is a bad one.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Cause therefore that you put on her something of that which we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps it flows from her the blood of an artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster with that which is in it for the stenosis, so that the place heals.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of herself with the rest of the cure, until she is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary that you should keep from every person all the blood within the quantity of his own virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And that which appears from the bright color on the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let her not come out, until she reddens; and likewise if she appears gross, then let her not come out, until she becomes subtle; and likewise if it is sharp, then let the sharpness be taken away from it.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary that he who is full, strong, and resistant to the extraction of blood should have a single force, so as to increase the bloodletting from a young one, and to be a bleeder on his side; and in him who is weak, to be the opposite of that.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary that he should take himself out in twos, and that there be a tight hole; and it is better that it should be administered in the bloodletting from a young one, so that it is a turned section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this mode of bloodletting is healthier than the flow of blood, and from the incision of a nerve; and it is more praiseworthy, and healthier than the bloodletting by width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And he who has become accustomed to a syncopation of the pulse should eat a little bread infused with water of grapefruit before phlebotomy; or, if he is warm, then secaniabin: and let him draw out blood into three or four vessels.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if his complexion is cold, then he should take a little bread infused with syrup of myrrh, or with syrup of honey aromatized with spices, or with aromatic syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If a syncopation should occur during phlebotomy, and it is due to an exit of blood from many vessels: then he should take, in a cup, water of meat, and syrupy substance that is fragrant; and let him apply aromaticity with aloe, and open his chest while doing so: and let him use the other things which we have said in the division on syncopation from exhaustion in relation to bloodletting.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	But he who wants to stop his arm from bleeding and to make his blood flow again: it is necessary for him that the phlebotomy which stops a lot of blood loss be done with small force in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	But he who wants to stop his arm from bleeding and to make his blood flow again, and his body is strong: then let him do it after seven or nine hours since his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	But he who wants to draw blood from his body in the opposite direction of the part to which it declines: it is necessary that he do this in the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In the body of which there is much blood already warmed and activated, and it causes fever: it is necessary that he leave it from there in a single direction, and draw out a large quantity of it: and make its opening larger until a syncopation occurs: after you have kept all the conditions of bloodletting: and let you place your hand on its pulse during the flow of blood, so that no death should occur at the place of a syncopation.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For this reason it happened that when the phlebotomist did not know, and he fell because of negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not appropriate that when you are going to cut the arm and draw the blood in a second, if the orifice of the vein has already been closed, and let the exit of the blood be difficult, so that he presses on himself with sudden motion, and let him bend quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For this is a bad thing, far from it, until you have left yourself, unless the phlebotomist draws blood in a second.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or take away with you the acuteness of phlebotomy that which is coagulated from blood in the orifice of the vein, and put on yourself some dissolved salt in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And put on yourself some tar-oil or green-worts, and put the compression on the body part, until blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	But if the vein is already open, then let it go, and do not press on it, until it is closed.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	What if necessity compels to draw blood a second time, and there is no excuse, then either phlebotomize the person above that place, or in an arm on another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	But the vein of the arm is phlebotomized at the place of the foot, and the Basilica, if they are not found, and are hidden, because it is composed from them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of phlebotomy is, so that it puts his hand in hot water, until he feels a throbbing pain, and the vein appears clearly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then tighten the ligature on top of it with slight compression.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then phlebotomize a second time, gradually, not transversally, and not according to the length: and let the opening be wide, and your phlebotomy let it go a little above the knuckle.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	What if the blood is not coming out, then again put your hand in hot water, and let the blood run into the water, until you satisfy your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	But if you are in the summer days, then you are absolved from the washing of your hands in warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And indeed, it is put forth that a great deal of the blood flow is in warm water in the time of winter.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And phlebotomy of this vein is salutary for all veins, because there is no pulsation under it, nor are the nerves affected.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	Phlebotomy of the right hand, indeed, is salutary for diseases of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of phlebotomy is such that you should squeeze the hand with a ligature, or your own hand, after you have put it into warm water, until the vein is contracted, and is evident to the touch.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then phlebotomize it by passing over it.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it entirely, it will not hurt it in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And preserve your hand, so that you do not phlebotomize it again.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Under it are the nerves of the fingers bare from the flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then repeat your hand to the warm water, and let the blood run in it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not repeat your hand in warm water, the blood will clot in the orifice of the vein, and the flow will be prevented.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	But when you extract a quantity of blood that is necessary, then put oil and salt on the vein: so that it does not congeal quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And likewise, you should do the same for all the branches that are tight.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The grip of phlebotomy is from the left hand, because it is salutary for diseases of the spleen: and likewise do the same in phlebotomizing it as you did in the second equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The grip of phlebotomizing the saphenous vein is for ailments that are in the lower part of the body, such as ailments of the womb, and retention of menstruation, diseases of the kidneys and bladder, old sores of the legs and buttocks, and similar ailments from ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of phlebotomy is so that the sick person puts his foot into hot water; and he rubs it until the blood comes out; and he ties a bandage over the foot with a thong.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And the vein is indeed at the heel, visible towards the thumb; and many branches come out of it on the face of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	So phlebotomize it either in a larger branch of it or at the heel in a cluster of veins; for it is better and healthier.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If you phlebotomize it on the face of the foot, then be careful of the nerves that are beneath it on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your phlebotomy where you phlebotomize it across from each other, so that you do not want to wound it: and let the phlebotomist be calm.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If, however, the exit of the blood is prevented, then turn his foot again into hot water; and let the blood not run into it until it has drained out.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	That if the vein that the phlebotomist hits is in the first pulse, then continue with phlebotomy to the upper part somewhat, since the place is healthier and you do not want to harm it out of it when you are pulling from it, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And likewise with the saphenous vein of the other foot equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	But the location of the sciatic veins, as we have said, is at the heel from the side of the tree.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the quality of phlebotomy is, to a pain in the leg, when it is due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of phlebotomy is, so that the sick person takes a hot bath and it cools off; and he ties his thigh from the side of the tree up to the heel with a long slender string: for it does not appear otherwise because of it.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When then appears, then phlebotomize it according to whatever skill you have possible, or across from each other; and it is better, or as if you had wounded it with an incision, or cut it with a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For this reason it is salutary; and itself is concealed to a great extent in many men.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	For if you do not inject it and it does not appear at all to the sense: then take some blood from one of its veins and that which appears on the back of the foot, and towards the ear: and cut off from the nerves, and make it run out a quantity as much as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then bind tightly, and place flesh over the place of phlebotomy, and squeeze the spot.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	For it heals quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	Of Ventosaation, and quality of use of it.
Caput XCVIII.	CHAPTER LXXVIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Of the ventosations, they are made from horns, and from air, and from heat.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And the ventosation is made in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	When with scarification and extraction of blood: and the other is a ventosation without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this ventosation which is without scarification, is in two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or indeed it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the ventosations which are administered with scarification and extraction of blood, are fourteen places of the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of which one is the Ventosation of the Lord, and it is at the end of the head: and Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck: and the ventosations of Alhagdahim, and they are two laminae of the neck from the two parts simultaneously: and the ventosation of the mind, and it is under the mandible in the lower mouth: and the ventosations of the two spatulas: and the ventosation of Alachosos at the end of the tail: and the ventosations of the two flames, and they are in the middle of the two arms: and the ventosations of the two crura: and the ventosation of the two cauillae.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And the ventosation also does not extract blood from your small veins scattered in the flesh, and because of this its power does not come from them, as is the case with the phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	It is not necessary that wound dressing be done with fire or without fire in any disease that happens from fullness until the whole body is drained.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity requires wound dressing because of illness or out of custom, we shall administer it at any time in the beginning, in the end and in the middle of the month and at any other time.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	That is because a person is suffering from headache and vomiting when blood multiplies within him until he needs to be drained by wound dressing, but he does not find it until he has passed stool.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And among them is the one who finds fullness and redness on his face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And among them is the one who finds itching on his face, forehead, darkness, and numbness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And among them is the one who scratches the place where he wound dressing was applied.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And among them is the one whose laughter multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And among them is the one who finds blood taste in his mouth, or he spits with his tongue and spits out the blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And among them is the one whose dream multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And among them is the one who sees blood and redness, killed people, plagues, and similar things in his sleep.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When we see something from among them, and especially if it is in the middle of the third month: We then order wound dressing to be done after having passed two or three hours since daybreak.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	However, the wound dressing of the nose is: because it brings about headache in the head, and because it drips into the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But it is necessary that that be done after draining the whole body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this Wound dressing is for the case of phlebothrombosis of the head.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not allowed to use wound dressing on someone who has a cold complexion, or in a place that is catarrhal.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For this Wound dressing causes a great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	Since they shouldn't use these when their heads are cold and have diseases that cause coldness.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	But if a man is patient with it, forgetfulness comes to him.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And for this reason, it is fitting that you order the person who uses it to put his hand down a little when he is blowing out, fearing the generation of forgetfulness.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Blowing out, or Al-Kohl, is the place of phlebotomy of Fusca, and phlebotomy of Basilica, and for this reason it confers ash, constriction of anhelosis, and fissures of the instrument of anhelosis, and coughs, and filling.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it is fitting that it be blown out by Al-Kohl a little, because if it is put down, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Blowing out, however, is the cause of pains in the head and eyes, and hemiplegia, and perforations, and pain in the roots of the teeth; and it is the place of phlebotomy of Basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is fitting that you order the person who blows out not to put his hand on the scarification: lest he strike an artery, and blood flow.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	But if he blows out under his chin, it brings alcohol into the mouth, and corruption of the gingival, and similar ailments that are in the mouth; and it is the place of phlebotomy of Aliherich, which are in the two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	But if he blows out with a spatula, it brings to Al-Kohl, which is made by reflexion, and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	Blowing out from the interior parts of the two foci brings assistance to phlebotomy of the new three, Basilica, and Fusca, and Cephalica: for it itself attracts blood from all those small veins that are in the flesh; and these small veins attract those grosser veins from others, until the attraction comes to the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	It is necessary that you do not let Ventosator go too far with scarification because the place is stripped of flesh and below it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	But if Ventosa goes too far on the back of the thigh, it causes hemorrhoids in the anus and ulcers at the bottom.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is necessary that you order Ventosator to make the wound large and of brass because the place needs strong suction and perhaps the thin Ventosas break: and let there be a large scarification.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	But the Ventosas of the legs diminish visibly because they draw blood from all the body and cause old pains in the veins and ligaments and blisters: they bring on periods, and produce both the menstrue and anemias, and excitement; and stand at the place of phlebotomy of the two saphenous veins and the alhorcobeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	However, they weaken the body greatly, and cause fainting in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the support of the alhorcobeni is near to the support of the two legs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the Ventosas is that you place the wound first in a hollow, and drain with moderate suction; and do not prolong the position of the Ventosas, but put them quickly, and shake them quickly so that the humors come to the opening equally: and do not cease to repeat this and continue, until you see the place already red and swollen, and the redness of blood appears; then therefore scarify, and repeat suction slowly.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider in the disposition of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For he who is of tender flesh and rare porridge, should scarify himself once only, not more: lest the place should ulcerate.Et uelos quae sunt corporis uentosa, et qui in subluna sunt, scutiantur sedecem diem, non plus: sed primum ponas uentosam in pratis,
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And let the Ventosas that are on the body, and which are in the belly, rub for sixteen days, not more: but first let him who has the wound make it large, a little more shall he make it: and let him temper suction in ease, and quickness, and shaking.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is a thickening in the blood, then it should be cut twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In wine indeed the first opening of the avenue of the refinement of blood, and its hydration: and in the second indeed the close scrutiny of the thorough extraction of thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If indeed the blood is very foul, then let the incision be made three times: that the last consequence may be obtained.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And to the last, when we wish to extract blood little by little, or a little less, one incision is sufficient for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	That if we wish to extract blood many times, we make several incisions.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure that the blood is thick: then it should be cut deeply; and the equal term in the incision, is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What is that which should be administered from oils concerning the positioning of the wind, and what cauterizes the wind.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	IN that which has a thick, tough, dark skin, and whose pores are closed, it is necessary to spread the places of the Wind with open, soothing, relaxing oils: if it is in the time of summer, as is the oil of the alker, or the oil of castor-oil, or the oil of almonds, or the oil of pumpkin-seed.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in the time of winter, then olive-oil, or rose-water-oil, or chamomile-oil, or pomegranate-salt: and similar ones.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If indeed the excess is thick, cold: then let there be bitter-oil, or oil of myrrh, or white-oliver-oil, or red-crown-oil: and similar ones.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If indeed the wind is of wide pores, tender flesh: then it should be prevented from oil, and it should be washed with rose-water, or cold water, or spring-water, or pumpkin-water, or porter's-water: and similar ones.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	But he whose blood is of a watery nature, let him wash with vinegar, or with myrtle water, and sumac: and similar things.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	But he whose fluid excesses are coarse, let him wash with old wine, or with water of samphire, or with a decoction of aniseed, or of camomile: and similar things to these.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is necessary that the washing-out should be done in a bath, or in a tub; and also that he should receive a medicine after leaving the bath for an hour, or for two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it is not necessary that anyone should sleep after washing-out.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What is needed so that the person may be treated with a bloodletting, or with phlebotomy, before the washing-out?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after this, consider first of all: if the person is cholerical, and the sharpness and inflammation of his blood are increased by bloodletting or phlebotomy; then let him take something cooling, like pomegranate; also lettuce, vinegar, and mint, and mint tea, and fennel-seed.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And put on his food dishes of downy stuff, and meats that are wet, and cooked food with apples: and similar things.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And if the person's complexion is cold, let him drink in a cup syrup of honey, or of alfalfa, or of mint-seed made; and he should drink medium-strong wine, which is between old and new: and let him be directed to eat in moderation.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And put on his food downy stuff, and birches: and doves, that is, many birds: and let him eat pigeon-meat.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it is necessary that the drink after washing-out and phlebotomy should be stronger than the food; and let it be given in a cup to some men in a strong wine, or in a medicine of musk, that is, musket, or in alselin water; before the washing-out: and before phlebotomy, or after: so as to strengthen the main limbs, and to refine the blood.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	They should not take it from a hot beverage.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	On the wound, without scarification.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	But those that are without scarification, and that are put on the skin, and the spleen, and the podagra, and over the bowels, and the places of the ribs, and the side, and the belly: for these members do not bear the scarification above them.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And it is not sought through them, unless it be an attack from the blood of a member to a member: for we put the ventosae over the breasts in a fever of the blood of the nose.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we make use of them, to remove from a member a cold wet pain that is in the member: for we put the ventosae over the bowels, and the umbilicus.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	For she tightens the member, and warms it, and takes away the pain for that reason, because she has resolved the uentosity.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	And is also put on the ribs, when there happens to them an obstruction, or a stone.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	For his own virtue of its attraction may possibly open an obstruction, or it removes a stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And likewise does when it is put on the skin, and the spleen for the purpose of cooling an inflammation in both: for it cools the inflammation.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	And these ventosae are administered with a few cuts only.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And they are sometimes administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And sometimes they are administered full of warm water in a fever of pleurisy: and that is, so that the ventosae may be filled, and large, with warm water alone, or with water in which have been boiled the herbs that are suitable.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	Form of the winds administered with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	Let the width of its opening be that of two open fingers, according to which we form it: and let the quantity of it be in the depth half a palm: and let it be in the back of its place, which is around the middle of it, a little hole, according to the quantity that is put into it: let it be made of copper, or of brass, smooth-edged, equal, sharp-edged: that it may not wound the member at its position on it: and let there be in the middle of it a wire of copper, or of iron, where the candle with fire is placed.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	And this well-known wound has now healed greatly, greater than that which we have told, and somewhat smaller than that one, according to the sickness and age of him who used it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	For the winds of young men do away with them, and some others, as much as the winds of old men, and of great bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	The quality of such a wound as this is, that you kindle the fire with the hay, or candle, and place it on the middle of the arm that lies across the middle of the wound, so that the fire does not burn the body of the wounded.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	Then place it on the body, and the finger on the hole that I have said, until we hold the wound closed: while we are holding it closed, take away the finger, and the steam will come out through the hole and close the wound at once.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	Then set fire to the hay according to its habit, and light it again if you like that one.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	But in the wound that is being treated with pleurisy water, there is no crosswise arm and no hole; it is not administered, unless it is filled with water and placed on the body only.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	And this wound is the better because it can hold a lot of water.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	Of the suspension of blood-sugar.
Caput XCIX.	Chapter LIX.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	Blood-sugar is not administered in many cases, unless the member is unable to hold a wound, because of its smallness, like the lip, and gums, and such things.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	Or on a bare member, deprived of flesh, like the finger, and nose, and such things.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	And the quality of their use is: that you should take them from blood-sugar which is in sweet water, clean from腐敗.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	Then they are to be removed in the day and in the night out of sweet water, until they become thirsty, and there remains nothing in their stomachs.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	Then the body is to be drained first with phlebotomy, and then with venesection.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	Then wash the limb well with water until it turns red.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	Then bandage the wound.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	When it has healed a little and the wound falls, and suction is possible at the site with venesection, then it is more beneficial to treat with bandages; and if not, then wash the place with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	Then with much water, and rub, and squeeze.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	If the course of blood is prolonged after the fall of blood-letting, and it is a resorption: then immerse a linen cloth in cold water, and place it on top, until the resorption comes away.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	If the blood increases, then sprinkle powder on top of the wound, crushed oak-moisture, or similar things from astringent: until the blood comes away.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	Or bandage the place with half-raw herb-juices: and let them alone, until the herbs stick to the place, because the blood has dried up.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	And it is necessary if the blood-letting is necessary, when it is possible, to change them.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	If, however, blood-letting is forbidden by suspension, then wash the place with recent blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	Or wrap it up now in places, until someone comes out with some of the blood.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	Then bandage them, for they themselves, when they feel some of the blood, stick immediately.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	When you wish to make them fall, sprinkle on them something from crushed aloe, or salt, or ash: and they will fall immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	¶ End of Second Part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	¶ The Third Part of the Surgical Book by Al-Buqā'ī.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	¶ A Universal Discourse on Restoration, Dislocation, Cure of Twisting, and Similar Matters.
Caput I.	¶ First Book.
